data.title: Famous Actors From Queens
data.meta_description: Caan in 1976 during the filming of A Bridge Too Far Photo: Nationaal Archief Creative Com­mons Attribution- Share Alike 3.0 Netherlands. Many stars on the screen have roots in Queens and we are going to look at just a few of them. First, it would be remiss not to take this op­portunity to reflect on
data.text:
Many stars on the screen have roots in Queens and we are going to look at just a few of them.

First, it would be remiss not to take this op­portunity to reflect on the life and career of the recently passed James Caan. Though born in the Bronx, Caan grew up in Sunnyside with his mother, Sophie, and father, Arthur. He at­tended Michigan State University and later transferred to Hofstra University. Although he never graduated from Hofstra, this was the place where he found a passion for acting. He went on to study at New York City’s Neigh­borhood Playhouse School of the Theatre for five years. Throughout his career, Caan has acted in 137 roles. Some of his most notable roles in film include Brian’s Song (1971), The Godfather (1972), The Gambler (1974), Mis­ery (1990), and Elf (2003). James Caan’s final movie, Fast Charlie, will be released in 2023. James Caan has won 8 awards and has re­ceived 21 nominations. His memory will live on in his films and in Queens.

Martin Scorsese is extremely accom­plished in the film industry as a director, actor, and screenwriter. Scorsese was born in Flush­ing and his family moved to Little Italy, Man­hattan when he was young. His parents, Charles and Catherine, shared a passion for acting while also working in the Garment Dis­trict. Due to his asthma, Scorsese was limited to what he could do as a child, which led him to cinema. He received his B.A. in English from New York University’s (NYU) College of Arts and Science, formerly known as Wash­ington Square College, in 1964. He went on to earn his M.A. from NYU’s Steinhardt School of Culture, Education, and Human De­velopment, formerly known as School of Ed­ucation, in 1968. Scorsese has directed 67 projects in his career; some to note are Who’s That Knocking at My Door? (1967), Taxi Driver (1976), Goodfellas (1990), The Wolf of Wall Street (2013), and The Irishman (2019). He’s acted in 37 roles, notably Martin plays himself in the twelfth episode of the fifth sea­son of Entourage, titled Return to Queens Blvd. He is accredited as the screenplay writer of 17 films and series, such as Casino (1995), The Age of Innocence (1993), and Silence (2016). Scorsese has won 170 awards and has been nominated 283 times.

Jon Favreau, actor, director, and screen­writer, was born in Flushing in 1966 to Madeleine and Charles. Madeleine worked as an elementary school teacher and his father was a special education teacher. Favreau at­tended Queens College and dropped out early to start his career as a comedian in Chicago. His filmography as an actor is very impressive, as he has played 73 roles. His first acting role was as Chicago Taxi Driver in Folks! (1992) and his most recent was as Happy Hogan in Spider-Man: No Way Home (2021), a role he has reprised eight times in the Marvel Cine­matic Universe. Favreau is accredited as di­rector of 26 projects, most notably Made (2001), Elf (2003), Zathura: A Space Adven­ture (2005), Iron Man (2008), The Jungle Book (2016), and Chef (2016). He has written movies such as Swingers (1996), and televi­sion shows, including 12 episodes of The Mandalorian (2019-2020). Favreau has won 11 awards and has been nominated 27 times.

Actress Amy Ryan was born in Flushing to Pamela and John. Her stage name was cho­sen after her mother’s maiden name and her birth name is Amy Beth Dziewiontkowski. Her mother worked as a nurse and her father owned a trucking business. After graduating from New York’s High School of Performing Arts, Ryan worked on the national tour of Biloxi Blues, and continued her career on Broadway for a decade. Her filmography is extensive, as she’s acted in 71 movies and se­ries. Some to note are Gone Baby Gone (2007), Before the Devil Knows You’re Dead (2007), The Office (2008-2011), and Beautiful Boy (2018). Ryan has won 39 awards and has received 29 nominations.

Christopher Walken was born in Astoria to Rosalie and Paul. Paul owned Walken’s Bak­ery in Astoria. Christopher Walken’ birth name is Ronald Walken, after actor Ronald Colman. Walken and his brothers, Kenneth and Glenn, were child actors on television series in the ‘50s, such as The Wonderful John Acton (1953) and The Motorola Television Hour (1954). As an actor, he’s accredited with 140 roles, including The Deer Hunter (1978), Bat­man Returns (1992), Pulp Fiction (1994), and Hairspray (2007). Walken has won 25 awards and has received 34 nominations.

Actress and screenwriter Awkwafina was born in Stony Brook and grew up in Forest Hills. Her birth name is Nora Lum, and Awk­wafina, her stage name, is her alter personality. Her mother, Tia, died when she was four years old and her father, Wally, works in information technology. Her paternal grandfather used to own a Cantonese restaurant in Flushing called Lum’s. Awkwafina attended Fiorello H. La­Guardia High School of Music & Art and Per­forming Arts and graduated from SUNY Albany in 2011. She has played 38 roles, no­tably Ocean’s 8 (2018), Crazy Rich Asians (2018), The Farewell (2019), Shang-Chi and the Legend of the Ten Rings (2021), and her own show Awkwafina is Nora from Queens (2020-2021) which she also writes for. In Awkwafina Is Nora from Queens, she plays herself as a young adult in Flushing trying to live and learn with help from her father and grandmother. Awkwafina has won 13 awards and has received 39 nominations.

—Anna Stiesi
